paper_abstract: It is shown that equations of the form phi(X) = psi(X), in which the unknown X is a set of natural numbers and phi, psi use the operations of union, intersection and addition of sets S + T = {m + n | m is an element of S, n is an element of T}, can simulate systems of equations phi(j) (X(1), ..., X(n)) = phi(j)(X(1), ..., X(n)) with 1 <= j <= l, in the sense that solutions of any such system are encoded in the solutions of the corresponding equation. This implies computational universality of least and greatest solutions of equations phi(X) = psi(X), as well as undecidability of their basic decision problems. It is sufficient to use only singleton constants in the construction. All results equally apply to language equations over a one-letter alphabet Sigma = {a}.
paper_title: Univariate Equations Over Sets of Natural Numbers
